questions.prompt: The Fourier coefficient formula is cₖ =:
questions.explanation: The analysis equation cₖ = (1/T)∫x(t)e^(-jkω₀t)dt extracts the k-th harmonic coefficient. The 1/T factor normalizes by period. Integration is over any complete period. Note the negative sign in the exponent.
For k=0, the exponential e^0 = 1, so c₀ = (1/T)∫x(t)dt. This is just the average value of x(t) over one period. It's the DC component, representing any constant offset in the signal.
By definition or L'Hopital's rule, sinc(x) = sin(πx)/(πx) approaches 1 as x→0. This is crucial because many Fourier transforms involve sinc, and knowing its value at origin helps sketch spectra.

questions.prompt: For an odd signal, Fourier coefficients cₖ are:
questions.explanation: Odd symmetry x(-t) = -x(t) forces coefficients to be purely imaginary. This follows from the integral property: odd function times e^(-jkω₀t) over symmetric limits yields imaginary result only.

questions.prompt: For an even signal, Fourier coefficients cₖ are:
questions.explanation: Even symmetry x(-t) = x(t) forces coefficients to be real. The imaginary parts cancel when integrating an even function times e^(-jkω₀t) over a symmetric interval. Phase is 0 or π.

questions.prompt: A rectangular pulse train has cₖ envelope shaped like:
questions.explanation: Pulse train coefficients follow cₖ = (Aτ/T)·sinc(kτ/T). The sinc envelope determines how coefficients decay with k. Narrower pulses have wider sinc envelope, meaning more high-frequency content.

questions.prompt: For a square wave with 50% duty cycle, c₂ =:
questions.explanation: A 50% duty cycle square wave has zero coefficients at even harmonics. The symmetric structure causes cancellation. Only odd harmonics survive: c₁, c₃, c₅, etc. This is characteristic of half-wave symmetry.

questions.prompt: sinc(n) for nonzero integer n equals:
questions.explanation: sinc(n) = sin(nπ)/(nπ) = 0 for all nonzero integers n because sin(nπ) = 0. The sinc function has zeros at all nonzero integers. Only at n=0 does sinc(n) = 1.

questions.prompt: If x(t) has no DC component, then:
questions.explanation: No DC means average value is zero, so c₀ = (1/T)∫x(t)dt = 0. The signal oscillates equally above and below zero. Examples: pure sinusoids, balanced AC signals.

questions.prompt: The synthesis equation reconstructs x(t) using:
questions.explanation: The synthesis equation x(t) = Σcₖe^(jkω₀t) adds up all harmonic components. Each cₖe^(jkω₀t) is a rotating phasor at frequency kω₀. The sum recreates the original periodic signal.
